Award.AwardTitle: Moduli Spaces of Holomorphic Curves: Properties and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
String theory is a model that represents elementary particles by vibrating strings with the aim of unifying the four fundamental forces of nature. While string theory is one of the main paradigms in physics today, it has yet to make experimentally testable predictions. However, it has generated many mathematical predictions that have led to fundamental developments in algebraic geometry and symplectic topology, especially in relation to (pseudo-) holomorphic curves. This project aims to further test string theory mathematically, while deepening the mathematical understanding of such curves with an eye toward applications to more classical problems in geometry. Some of the projects in this work will be pursued by graduate students and other junior researchers in collaboration with the investigator.

This project has four distinct directions at the juncture of algebraic geometry, symplectic topology, and string theory. It will explore connections between the rigidity of pseudo-holomorphic curves in symplectic topology and birational algebraic geometry. It will study the local structure of moduli spaces of stable morphisms of genus 2 and higher, with the aim of later applications in mirror symmetry and enumerative geometry. The PI will also apply his method for computing genus 1 Gromov-Witten invariants to more targets, with the aims of verifying predictions of string theory predictions in additional cases. The fourth direction aims to develop positive-genus real Gromov-Witten theory and its relations with open string theory and real enumerative geometry.

This award is jointly funded by the Algebra and Number Theory and Geometric Analysis programs.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Stony Brook
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
String theory is a model that represents elementary particles by vibrating strings with the aim of unifying the four fundamental forces of nature. While string theory is one of the main paradigms in physics today, it has yet to make experimentally testable predictions. However, it has generated many mathematical predictions that have led to fundamental developments in algebraic geometry and symplectic topology, especially in relation to (pseudo-) holomorphic curves.

This just completed project lies in Gromov-Witten theory, the main link between mathematics and string theory. Its aims were to develop new mathematical notions that would allow furher testing of the mathematical predictions of string theory, to study in depth already established mathematical notions, and to apply them to more classical problems in geometry. The mathematical outputs of this project include development of real Gromov-Witten theory in positive genera that confirmed some of the related expectations of string theory and provided lower bounds for counts of real curves of positive genera in some real projective manifolds; these counts correspond to solutions of algebraic equations with real coefficients. This project has established the local structure of moduli spaces of stable morphisms of genus 2, preparing the foundation for concrete applications to come. It has provided a symplectic topology analogue of normal crossings degeneration of algebraic geometry, allowing for a more flexible approach to the long-running Gross-Siebert program for a direct verification of some mirror synnetry preditions of string theory. The PI's graduate student working on this project has introduced a new framework into the previously established real Gromov-Witten theory in genus 0, allowing for the much awaited study of its properties and applications. 

This project has resulted in 11 research publications and pre-prints, including a 250-page monograph establishing key structural results in real Gromov-Witten theory that are intended to facilitate future progress in the field. It has also produced 5 expository publications and pre-prints on different aspects of Gromov-Witten theory. This project has enabled one of the PI's graduate students to complete his PhD thesis, with further applications since then, including to correct past work by experts in the field, and another of the PI's graduate students to have a spectacular start to her research.


Last Modified: 07/20/2019
Modified by: Aleksey Zinger
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: String theory is a model that represents elementary particles by vibrating strings with the aim of unifying the four fundamental forces of nature. While string theory is one of the main paradigms in physics today, it has yet to make experimentally testable predictions. However, it has generated many mathematical predictions that have led to fundamental developments in algebraic geometry and symplectic topology, especially in relation to (pseudo-) holomorphic curves. This just completed project lies in Gromov-Witten theory, the main link between mathematics and string theory. Its aims were to develop new mathematical notions that would allow furher testing of the mathematical predictions of string theory, to study in depth already established mathematical notions, and to apply them to more classical problems in geometry. The mathematical outputs of this project include development of real Gromov-Witten theory in positive genera that confirmed some of the related expectations of string theory and provided lower bounds for counts of real curves of positive genera in some real projective manifolds; these counts correspond to solutions of algebraic equations with real coefficients. This project has established the local structure of moduli spaces of stable morphisms of genus 2, preparing the foundation for concrete applications to come. It has provided a symplectic topology analogue of normal crossings degeneration of algebraic geometry, allowing for a more flexible approach to the long-running Gross-Siebert program for a direct verification of some mirror synnetry preditions of string theory. The PI's graduate student working on this project has introduced a new framework into the previously established real Gromov-Witten theory in genus 0, allowing for the much awaited study of its properties and applications. This project has resulted in 11 research publications and pre-prints, including a 250-page monograph establishing key structural results in real Gromov-Witten theory that are intended to facilitate future progress in the field. It has also produced 5 expository publications and pre-prints on different aspects of Gromov-Witten theory. This project has enabled one of the PI's graduate students to complete his PhD thesis, with further applications since then, including to correct past work by experts in the field, and another of the PI's graduate students to have a spectacular start to her research.
